title: Cellular Senescence and Aging
content: Unity Biotechnology is developing senolytic medicines—molecules that target and destroy senescent cells in the human body. The science of cellular senescence impacts the aging process. Senolytics may delay, prevent, treat, or even reverse age-related diseases, including cancer, cardiovascular disease, and neurodegenerative disease.

title: Role of Cellular Senescence in Aging and Cancer
content: Cellular senescence plays a role in aging and cancer. The history of senescence in scientific study reveals a cellular senescence paradox. Medicines are being developed that target cellular senescence.

title: Senescent Cell Elimination
content: The search for a molecule that could eliminate senescent cells is ongoing. An example of senescent cell elimination is seen in osteoarthritic knees. Removing senescent cells may extend lifespan.

title: Senolytic Molecule Example
content: A senolytic molecule example is seen in the reversal of macular degeneration. The future of senescent cell targeting is promising.

title: Cellular Senescence and Metabolic Syndrome
content: Cellular senescence plays a role in metabolic syndrome.

title: Cellular Senescence and Brain Health
content: Cellular senescence also impacts brain health.

title: Training principles for longevity
content: Longevity would be the ability to use what I know how to do just science, biology, and be able to change how we get to live our lives, to be free of these indignities. Aging is not a rigid thing, it’s flexible and malleable. Nature has control knobs that can be twisted by humans, such as with drug development.

title: Preventing cardiovascular disease
content: The latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more.

title: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent
content: Discussion on the pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

title: Alzheimer's disease and lifestyle factors
content: Alzheimer's disease risk can be impacted by factors such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more. Blood pressure is an important modifiable lifestyle factor that can affect Alzheimer's disease risk. Exercise reduces the risk of Alzheimer's disease.

title: Exercise and cancer risk
content: Exercise may reduce the risk of cancer. The overarching impact of exercise on health, and the importance of focusing the factors that matter most.

title: Alcohol consumption and breast cancer risk
content: Impact of alcohol consumption on breast cancer risk and overall health.

title: Exercise as an intervention for poor sleep habits
content: Exercise can be used as an intervention for poor sleep habits.

title: Longevity benefits of consuming adequate protein and strength training
content: The longevity benefits of consuming adequate protein and strength training to preserve muscle mass and strength.

title: Fasting: weighing the risk vs. reward
content: Discussion on fasting and weighing the risk vs. reward.

title: Control knobs of aging
content: The control knobs of aging include calorie restriction, rapamycin, and mTOR, young blood, mitochondrial aging, methylation of DNA, and cellular senescence.

title: Methylome Reset and Aging
content: Twice in our lives we press a factory reset of your methylome: once at conception and then once more a few weeks into your life (for making germline cells in the sex organs). These are the only two times at this factory reset gets pressed. We now know you can do this artificially, thanks to the work of Shinya Yamanaka, who won the Nobel Prize in 2012. He identified a candidate list of genes that were turned on in this sort of embryological state and managed to weed it down to four, earning him the Nobel prize. However, just because you don’t have the methyl groups on your DNA doesn’t mean they translate into the phenotype that is youth.

title: Cellular Senescence and Aging
content: Cellular senescence is a cell that stops dividing and is no longer functional. But rather than go through apoptosis, it stays there. Kids don’t have these but as you age they start to accumulate. When you eliminate senescent cells from animals, they live on average about 30% longer and when they do die, they die with many of the features of aging either absent or reduced. The ability to make senescent cells is vitally important to our survival. A genetically engineered mouse that cannot make senescent cell will be full of tumors before it gets to reproductive age. The cellular senescent system is an anticancer system and you do not want to mess with the emergency brake.

title: Senescent Cells and DNA Damage
content: When a cell gets DNA damage, it first tries to repair it. If it can’t be repaired, it then “decides” whether to go down the path of apoptosis or senescence. However, we don’t understand how cells make a choice between the two. Senescent cells secrete into the micro environment around them stuff that distorts tissue function and contribute both to features of natural aging as well as very particular diseases of aging.

title: Senescence in Scientific Study
content: In the early 1960s, it was widely believed that cells from us from mammals could have infinite capacity to divide. However, a clever guy named Leonard Hayflick came along and coined this term, senescent cells, meaning cells that lose the ability to divide in culture. And he says something very prophetic… “this may contribute to features of aging”.

title: Developing Medicines that Target Cellular Senescence
content: Of all the possible “controls knobs” of aging, cellular senescence is the easiest one to drug. The question is: How do we make medicines that target a fundamental mechanism of aging? In 2011, a paper by Jan M. van Deursen suggested that the senescent cells were actually driving these features of aging. This led to the start of a company (Unity) that aimed to answer 4 specific questions: Do senescent cells contribute to natural aging? Could we find a disease, any human disease, that we could model in an animal where we can eliminate senescent cells and take that disease and either stop it or even better send it backwards? Could we find a molecule that could trigger the elimination of senescent cells from a living creature safely? Is getting rid of senescent cells safe?

title: Senescent Cells and Aging
content: The results were “really the trigger for de-stealthing the effort and speaking openly about what we’re doing because if it didn’t contribute to natural aging and it didn’t cause a particular disease of aging and we couldn’t find molecules, there was no company.” Before starting Unity (company created to try to make a drug that targets senescent cells), the four risks were: 1) What if senescent cells don’t contribute to natural aging? 2) What if they don’t cause a particular disease of aging that the FDA will approve as an indication? 3) What if you can never find a molecule to eliminate them? 4) What if eliminating them is unsafe?

title: Search for a Molecule to Eliminate Senescent Cells
content: The quest to answer question #3: Could we find a molecule that could trigger the elimination of senescent cells from a living creature safely? Early on, it was realized that there was the possibility that they could either a) eliminate the cells, or b) come up with ways to reduce the pathological SASP that these cells were creating. They decided to go with plan A because you wouldn’t have to dose the drug over and over again. In fact, you could potentially just take is one time, kill the cells, and sort of solve the issue. Many times, the “safety” of a drug becomes a problem because you have to take it a bunch, so this approach lowers that risk.

title: Senescent Cell Elimination in Osteoarthritic Knees
content: In a Phase 1 study, it was shown that when you eliminate senescent cells from the painful knee joint of a human being with osteoarthritis, a single administration of a senolytic medicine eliminates pain dramatically in these humans for “as long as we’ve looked”. In human beings, we have eliminated senescent cells from patients’ knees with a single injection of this drug. And we can not only eliminate or dramatically reduce pain, but we can also eliminate factors the senescent cells are making.

title: Extending Lifespan by Removing Senescent Cells
content: Atherosclerosis is another disease in which senescence plays a role. A paper in Science by Jan Van Deursen and Bennett Childs showed in rodents that senescent cells (SC) accumulate in the atherosclerotic plaques. And when you eliminate these senescent cells, you can 1) Reduce plaque volume 2) Thicken the fibrotic cap that forms on the surface of an atherosclerotic plaque (and therefore make it less clinically dangerous).

title: Impact of Drug on Chronic Diseases
content: Some diseases were dramatically reduced. The age effects of kidney function, cataracts, and spinal lordosis were impacted. These animals seem to preserve features of youthful behavior. Overall, the animals die of the same things but just later in life. One explanation is that there is something perverse that senescent cells do to the tissue microenvironment.

title: Implications in Cancer Treatment/Prevention
content: The [senescent cells] system is an anticancer system in the young could become a pro-cancer system in the old by doing something to the tumor microenvironment that makes it more amenable to tumorigenesis. A “two-hit” strategy could be a strategy in which you deliberately are trying to drive tumor cells into senescence and then killing them. Additionally, there are a series of cancers that we think that are age associated that may be essentially the product of a highly senescent environment: So cancers of the skin, cancers of the bladder. An interesting thought would be: Could you go in and eliminate senescent cells and change the trajectory of disease?

title: Senolytic Molecule Example in Macular Degeneration Reversal
content: Macular degeneration (MD) is an area in which senolytic medicines may play a role. Soon, Ned and team will be testing their first molecules into the human eye. They will start with a very select population to demonstrate safety and then branching outwards into multiple diseases of the eye. The clinical hypothesis: One or more of these progressive diseases of the aging eye will stop progressing when senescent cells are eliminated.

title: The Future of Senescent Cell Targeting
content: What will the future of targeting senescent cells (SCs) look like? It’s going to be a small number of things to target, context specific, and there’ll be super creative ways that we and others come up with to exploit these different vulnerabilities. Senescent cells on the other hand can’t divide by definition so their ability to access variation is dramatically reduced.

title: The Role of Cellular Senescence and Metabolic Syndrome
content: There is some data in support of senescence in that cellular niche, but it’s very complicated biology. It’s an area of intense literature debate. There was a large meta analysis of a genome wide association studies looking for the genetic correlation between illness of aging and loci.

title: The Role of Cellular Senescence and Brain Health
content: Ned’s group working on understanding the role of senescent cells and cognitive decline. Your brain has many glial cells. There’s a dramatic increase in senescent glial cells, specifically astrocytes and microglia. The question that needs to be studied: What would happen if you could eliminate senescent glial cells? Would that enhance cognition? Would it harm cognition?
